course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Metaphors in English and Chinese
course.description: A comprehensive study of metaphors in English and Chinese, not only as a rhetorical device, but also as an essential tool of our ordinary language and thought. The course encompasses a wide range of diverse topics such as literary metaphors, metaphors in everyday language (about time, life, change, quantity, love, anger, etc.), and metaphors in politics, mathematics, physics, artificial intelligence, and cyberspace. The approach is interdisciplinary and comparative, and most topics are to be discussed from a cross-linguistic and cross-cultural perspective. An ordinary reading knowledge of Chinese is required for enrollment.

reviews.author: 燃燒中的GPA
reviews.comment_content:
Cognitive linguistics, 主要研究日常生活中成日用到, 但唔易察覺到既conceptual metaphor同conceptual metonymy (係概念上的隱喻同轉喻, 而唔係文學修辭上用既novel/literary metaphor同metonymy)

8 modules:

1. Why Study Metaphor?
2. Traditional and Contemporary Views of Metaphor
3. Some Basic Concepts of the Contemporary Theory of Metaphor
4. TIME AS SPACE: A Contrastive Study of Chinese and English
5. Properties and Analysis of Conceptual Metaphor
6. Metaphorical/Metonymic Axes in Language
7. The Grounding of Conceptual Metaphors & Metaphor-Metonymy Interaction
8. Analyzing Polysemy with Metaphor and Metonymy

重點:

-Entailment

-Figure (F) & Ground (G); Trajector (TR), Landmark (LM) & Dominion (D)
[F = TR, G = LM + D]
e.g. The cat is on the chair.
F = the cat, G = on the chair; TR = the cat, LM = the chair, D = on

-Moving-Time, Moving-Ego

-Spatial perceptual strategies: Strategy A (Environment-projection), Strategy B1 (Canonical-encounter) & Strategy B2 (Sight-line alignment)
(其中一次attendance-taking其實係一個survey, 睇下大家對前後既語感, prefer Strategy B1定係B2, 見附件)

-Conceptual Metaphor [X IS Y: X is understood in terms of Y]
e.g. “嬲到爆”: ANGER IS A HOT FLUID IN A CONTAINER
X係一個我地想表達既抽象概念 (Target Domain), Y係一個我地用黎理解X既具體事物 (Source Domain), 呢個例子我地想表達抽象概念X (怒火, ANGER), 我地用一個具體事物Y (一個容器入面既熱流體, A HOT FLUID IN A CONTAINER) 黎理解X, 因為ANGER同A HOT FLUID IN A CONTAINER一樣, 就快爆出黎咁

-Conceptual Metonymy [Y for X: Y stands for X]
e.g. “開冷氣”: PRODUCT for INSTRUMENT
呢度既冷氣係指冷氣機, 我地講Y (冷氣, PRODUCT) 其實係stands for製造冷氣呢個PRODUCT既X (冷氣機, INSTRUMENT)

-Polysemy (用conceptual metaphor同conceptual metonymy分析中英文一字多義既現象)

reviews.author: zsheryl
reviews.title: Better than first impression but nothing more
reviews.comment_content:
I came into the course expecting to read a bunch of literary jargon, and possibly brush up my knowledge of idioms, proverbs and the like. However one important thing (I can't believe ) I failed to notice was that this is a course of CONCEPTUAL metaphors, not traditional/contemporary/literary metaphors, whatever you choose to name it. Some students have commented that the content is dry and uninteresting, because of clichés that recur throughout the course such as "TIME IS MONEY" and "LIFE IS A JOURNEY". However, "TIME IS MONEY" is very different from "time is money", in that the former is a categorical mapping of all related colloquial puns. For instance, "I spent so much time on the essay" falls into the category of TIME IS MONEY, because you are using the verb "spent" to describe time, much as you would do with money. This might seem like common sense, but wait till you learn about "FORESEEABLE FUTURE EVENTS ARE UP" and "IDEAS ARE FOOD". When you actually settle down to study (or cram right before a grade-changing exam), you'll realize that the crazily ungrammatical phrases actually start to make sense (and do keep in mind that although the phrases are unrealistic, they have their own unrealistic rules to follow...which I learnt after the sweat and tears of midterm grades:) There will be a lot of writing to do for the finals and the essay, but most of it will be manageable if you excel in the art of stringing together verbose terminology with grammatically comprehensible sentences~  
One interesting point during the course was when we had the opportunity to compare Chinese and English conceptual metaphors, which got me thinking about differences that never really occurred to me. Take this statement for example: "Christmas is coming, Christmas is here". In English, time can be seen as a moving entity towards us, and Christmas is a point in that moving time. However, in Chinese, we often find ourselves saying "快到圣诞节了", which treats the person as a moving entity heading towards a stationary point in time, Christmas.
Did I type too much...
reviews.comment_teaching: A lot of my friends missed lectures every now and then, as did I. (Hint, for our sem, he usually takes attendance twice in a row, then goes easy on us for a while) And even when I went, I never really gave the course my attention (apologies again). The professor basically drones on in the background while students sit and type at their computers. But Zhang min still enthusiastically carries on without a care in the world, and he really seems to be quite passionate about the material. However, if you're more accustomed to skipping classes and cramming before tests, at least have a friend to fill in your attendance for you (which itself requires a certain level of skill, since the TA counts how many students are sitting in a row, and hands out attendance slips accordingly...but she could always make a mistake, you never know;) and read the required reading. At least the first quarter of it. That will basically serve as your surrogate tutor.
reviews.comment_grading: I took this course to fulfill my (possible) HUMA minor, since it was rumored to be a somewhat easy course. Material wise, the course consists of 10 chapters, all of which will be posted on lmes. If you miss the lectures, the ppt will cover about 70-80% of the content discussed (not that I paid extreme attention to the lessons). In addition, there are required readings assigned to help you grasp the concepts (which I didn't quite finish reading either). There will be a midterm, a final and an essay, each about 20% of your grade (I forgot to save the syllabus, my apologies for the irresponsible estimations) with several single-question pop-quizzes that are given randomly for attendance only (not graded for accuracy).
reviews.comment_workload: In class midterm-ish quiz twice, a final, an essay, and random attendances you have to worry about. Don't ask me about the workload, I crammed everything so it seems insurmountable either way. But perhaps due to the fact that it was crammable, this course does give you a lot of free time during the semester.

reviews.comment_workload:
Overall, the materials you need to learn is very little because there is only two major topics which are conceptual metaphor and metonymy. Once you understand how to identify them, all you have to do is the exercise and past paper. Then you can get good grades in paper and exams.

The paper is very short. I only wrote less then 1 page but still got good score.

The exercise and past paper is very important to  the exams. They are provided on Canvas. Not a lot of revision is needed once you thoroughly understand the two major concepts.

You can write Chinese or English or both in your final exam, but it should be better to use English because the teaching is in English.

reviews.comment_content:
As suggested in the topic, it is about conceptual metaphors in both Chinese and English. Metonymy was also covered.

It is better for Chinese to take the course as many examples and exam questions were in Chinese. Most foreigners dropped the course after the first lesson.

Do not expect it to be a language course. It is more like understanding the logic in the metaphors. So fluency in English or Chinese wouldn't help that much as long as you can read.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching pace is quite slow and the tone of the professor was really boring so I didn't pay much attention in class. I just went to class for attendance taking. But the professor taught the materials in great detail(according to my minimal attention paid), so it would help on some topics that are difficult to grasp.

The power point slides basically got everything needed. I just read through the slides before quiz and exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 10%
10 Random attendance taken before the end of class.

Quiz: 20%
A simple quiz based on conceptual metaphor.

Assignment: 20%
It consists of 2 short essay questions.

Final exam: 50%
MC questions, short essays, and data-oriented problem solving questions.

I got 1 sd above mean for quiz, full attendance. Assignment and final scores were not released so I do not know how I performed. My final grade is satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say the workload is light as there are only 1 quiz, 1 assignment and final exam.

The quiz should be quite easy if you go through all the metaphors mentioned in class and those in past papers.

The assignment is also quite easy to handle and research materials are available online. A couple of hours would finish the work.

But expect the final exam is much more difficult than the quiz and questions require much more analysis and understanding on metaphors and metonymies. Past papers were provided for reference.
